title: Uppark Walks

images.title: Uppark house and grounds, 1987 by David Gearing, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Uppark house and grounds, 1987. Two years later in 1989 the house was to suffer a terrible fire. It has since been restored by the National Trust.

images.title: Chris Gunns / Uppark, garden
images.caption: Uppark, garden. The gardens were designed by Humphrey Repton

images.title: View towards Lawn Bottom from Uppark by Colin Pyle, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View towards Lawn Bottom from Uppark

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Vandalian Tower Ruins on Tower Hill. Ruins and viewpoint east of the house. It stands in the heart of the West Sussex countryside, yet its roots lie in America. The historical folly dates back to the 18th century. It was constructed to commemorate the British colony of Vandalia, a colony that eventually disappeared as the American colonies evolved. The Vandalian Tower is situated on the summit of Tower Hill and serves as a fascinating relic of the past. This folly, with its unique design and historical significance, adds a distinctive charm to the landscape.

images.title: The Vandalian Tower, Tower Hill by Tim Heaton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Today, the Vandalian Tower is owned by the descendants of the Fetherstonhaugh family, who also purchased the neighboring estate of Uppark. The Tower was recognised for its historical importance and was listed as a scheduled monument in 1976, ensuring its preservation for future generations to appreciate.

description: This walk visits the National Trust's Uppark House in South Harting West Sussex. The 17th-century house is surrounded by pleasant grounds with woodland and gardens to explore. The author H.G Wells stayed in the house during the late 19th century. The class divisions he observed here inspired his socialist views which later manifested themselves in work such as 'The Time Machine'. The house is located just a mile west of Harting Down where you can extend your outing on a number of good cycling and walking trails. You can also pick up the South Downs Way National Trail and climb to a fine viewpoint in this area. Queen Elizabeth Country Park, Iping Common and Stedham Common are other good local options.
